title: 'Chasing History' Review: Wishing on a Star

Moreover, that single occurrence refers not to a scandal or mixed-use architectural complex but to an old bit of Washington, D.C., geography, the piece of "the Potomac riverbank at Watergate." Throughout "Chasing History," the Washington Post appears not as the paper that made Mr. Bernstein famous but as competition to the one that made him a newsman, the old Evening Star. He tells the tale of a vanished, noisy print world in which "every page was composed, literally, within a rectangular metal form, called a 'chase,' that replicated the size of a newspaper page and served as a fence to contain the tens of thousands of pieces of type inside." Perhaps unintentionally, Mr. Bernstein's title is a play on words: his book is not so much about chasing after history as it is about "chasing" within those metal rectangles what's often called history's first draft.

There has never been a more beautifully modulated book about the deep-freeze of a human soul than "Mrs. Bridge." Evan S. Connell's 1959 novel is a masterpiece of understatement, its story culled from glimpses of the title character's drearily parochial existence as a lawyer's wife and country-club matron in Kansas City, Mo., between the wars. India Bridge passes through the rapidly changing American scene in a kind of self-willed trance: "There were half a dozen mirrors along the wall. Mrs. Bridge did not dare look into any of the mirrors, and as the four of them marched along she wondered if she was about to lose control of herself. Where are we going? she thought. Why are we here?"

title: 'Longing and Other Stories' Review: The Moon's Tears.
summary: Three tales from the Japanese writer Junichirō Tanizaki deal with characters facing emotional trials.. Neatly, conveniently, the life of the marvelous Japanese writer Junichirō Tanizaki divides into two all but equal portions. He was born in Tokyo in 1886, and resided there until the Great Kantō earthquake of 1923, when he relocated to the Kyoto-Osaka region, where he remained until his death in 1965. He was a controversial, successful writer during the Tokyo half of his life, but it was only after moving backward, to the environs of Japan's ancient capital, that he secured a place in the modern international pantheon.

title: Mysteries: 'A Thousand Steps' Review
summary: T. Jefferson Parker's mystery is also a coming-of-age tale set in the era of turning on and dropping out.. T. The Beatles are still putting out hit singles, Lyndon Johnson says the U.S. is winning the war in Vietnam and Timothy Leary is touting LSD as a psychological and spiritual cure-all. Making his cautious way through this social landscape is 16-year-old Matt Anthony, a budding artist whose ex-cop dad has been absent for years, whose loving mom now has a yen for opium, whose older brother is serving in Southeast Asia, and whose older sister Jasmine ("Jazz") has suddenly stopped coming home.
